metadata.title: Poly(ethylene imine)-modified magnetic halloysite nanotubes: A novel, efficient and recyclable catalyst for the synthesis of dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives

Poly(ethylene imine)-modified magnetic halloysite nanotubes: A novel, efficient and recyclable catalyst for the synthesis of dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives Zoleikha Hajizadeh Ali Maleki ⁎ Catalysts and Organic Synthesis Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, 16846-13114, Iran Catalysts and Organic Synthesis Research Laboratory Department of Chemistry Iran University of Science and Technology Tehran 16846-13114 Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A new magnetic nanocomposite, Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI, was prepared under mild conditions, fully characterized and applied as a heterogeneous catalyst for efficient synthesis of pyranopyrazole derivatives. In this study, a green magnetic nanocatalyst based on natural clay was fabricated. Magnetic nanoparticles were loaded on halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) and poly(ethylene imine) (PEI) was covalently grafted onto the surface of HNTs. The morphology and chemistry of the Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocomposite was fully characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy spectra, field-emission scanning electron micrograph (FE-SEM) images, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern and vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) curve analyses. These characteristics confirmed the successful synthesis of the nanocomposite. The catalytic performance of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI was utilized for the synthesis of pyranopyrazole derivatives. This heterogeneous catalyst exhibited high efficiency in green media under mild reaction conditions at room temperature and can be easily recovered from the reaction mixture by using an external magnet and reused for at least eight times without any significant decrease in catalytic activity. Keywords Halloysite Magnetite nanocatalyst Poly(ethylene imine) Multicomponent reaction Pyranopyrazoles 1 Introduction Magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles are the most employed nanoparticles which are used in biomedical, environmental and chemical applications. Owing to the magnetic properties and nanoscale size of magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs), they have the benefits of both heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts. Great dispersion of particles, high surface activity and simple separation method are among some of the benefits of MNPs [1]. To overcome disadvantages of MNPs such as agglomeration, immobilization of organic compounds onto MNPs is one of the most promising methods [2]. Halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) as a naturally occurring aluminosilicate clay minerals, have attracted considerable attention due to their negatively charged external surface (because of silicate groups) and positively charged internal surface (because of alumina groups) [3]. HNTs with porous structure have applied in several areas such as cosmetic [4], medicine [5], catalysis [6], tissue engineering [7] and environmental applications [8] because of their significant characteristics such as high stability in biological liquid, easy modification, low cost, good biocompatibility and high-water absorbency. Due to the presence of two kinds of hydroxyl groups in the inside and outside walls of HNTs, they can be modified by different functional groups. In the recent years, several reports have been found for the synthesis of magnetic functionalized HNTs. Due to the combination of MNPs on the surface of HNTs, they were found good separation ability. Furthermore, they were used in various applications such as reduction of nitrophenol [9], reduction of Cr(VI) [10], removal of methyl violet [11], and the adsorption of dyes [12]. One imperative water-soluble polymer, poly(ethylene imine) (PEI), has numerous amino groups in its branched chains [13]. Much attention has been paid to this structure due to its significant features such as gene delivery, antimicrobial activity and DNA neutralization ability [14] and significant adsorption ability for heavy metals [15]. Recently, several types of research have been reported in the field of immobilization of PEI on MNPs for modifying the surfaces of these nonmaterials [16]. Several reports have been presented for modifying the surface of HNTs by PEI. In these reports, PEI-functionalized HNTs were used for gas separation and as carbon dioxide adsorbents, gene delivery system and Cr(VI) removal [17–19], But, most of them suffer from disadvantages such as difficult recycling and recovering of nanocomposite. To synthesize organic compounds with respect to the environmental and green aspects, multicomponent reactions (MCRs) has received considerable attention in chemistry [20]. Most noteworthy features of MCRs are including atom economy, short reaction time and simplicity in the synthesis of complex structures. These class of reactions are applied for the production of various heterocyclic compounds such as pyranopyrazoles [21]. Pyranopyrazole heterocyclic compounds exhibit several applications like pharmacological and medicinal properties. Among pyranopyrazole heterocyclic derivatives, pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole has received much interest because of their anti-inflammatory [22] and insecticidal biological activities [23]. A number of synthesis methods using gamma alumina [24,25], magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles [26] and isonicotinic acid [27] as effective catalysts have been reported for the synthesis of pyranopyrazoles. However, there is still increasing attention has been paid to the growing role of natural-based nanocatalysts in development of heterocyclic synthesis with more efficient procedures. According to previous scientific reports to introduce novel recoverable organometallic nanocatalysts and their catalytic applications [28–30], herein, a novel and environmentally benign PEI-functionalized magnetic HNTs (Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI) is reported. It was characterized and applied in a multicomponent one-pot synthesis of dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives starting from hydrazine hydrate, ethyl acetoacetate, aromatic aldehydes and malononitrile in high-to-excellent yields at 40 °C (Scheme 1 ). This synthesized nanocatalyst was easily separated from the reaction mixture using a small external magnet and applied at least eight times without significant loss of catalytic activity. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of design, preparation, and characterization Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocatalyst and its application as a heterogeneous catalyst in the synthesize of dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives. 2 Experimental 2.1 General All the chemicals were purchased from Merck and Sigma-Aldrich and used without any purifications. Fourier transforms infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu IR-470 spectrometer by the method of KBr pellet. Field-emission scanning electron micrograph (FE-SEM) images were reported on a MIRA 3 TESCAN microscope with an attached camera. Elemental analysis of the nanocatalyst was carried out by energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis recorded Numerix DXP-X10 P. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were reported on a JEOL JDX–8030 (30 kV, 20 mA). Thermal analysis was taken by Bahr-STA 504 instrument. Magnetic measurements of the solid samples were performed using Lakeshore 7407 and Meghnatis Kavir Kashan Co., Iran vibrating sample magnetometers (VSMs). Melting points were measured on an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus and are uncorrected. 1H and 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX-500 Avance spectrometer at 500 and 125 MHz, respectively. 2.2 Preparation of Fe3O4@HNTs Initially, 0.5 g of Halloysite was added to a 100 mL solution of 0.23 g FeCl3·6H2O and 0.16 g of FeCl2·4H2O under N2 and 60 °C. To prepare iron oxide, 10 mL solution of (NH3, H2O) 8 mol/L was added dropwise to the initial mixture. The pH of the final mixture was controlled in the range of 9–10 and stirred for 4 h. Then, it was washed with distilled water 2 times. Finally, the obtained nanocomposite was dried at 100 °C for 3 h. 2.3 Preparation of Fe3O4@HNTs-3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane At first, 0.5 g of Fe3O4@HNTs were to 10 mL of toluene in a three-necked round-bottom flask under nitrogen atmosphere. The flask containing the reaction mixture was deaerated for 30 min with nitrogen and then heated with a heating mantle, followed by injection of 1 mL 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane into the flask at 60 °C. After that, the reaction mixture was refluxed at 120 °C for 20 h under constant stirring. The product was separated by simple filtration and washed a number of times with toluene and ethanol, respectively. Finally, the product was dried at 100 °C. 2.4 Preparation of Fe3O4@HNTs-propyltrimethoxysilane-PEI (Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI) A mixture of Fe3O4@HNTs-3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane (0.5 g) and KI (0.83 g) was added to a solution of PEI (0.75 g) and K2CO3 (1.72 g) in acetonitrile (25 mL) in a round-bottom flask and the mixture was stirred under reflux condition for 6 h. Finally, the obtained solid was collected from the solution by an external magnet and washed several times with water/ethanol followed by drying at 80 °C for 12 h. 2.5 General procedure for the synthesis of dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives 5a–l A mixture of ethyl acetoacetate 1 (2 mmol), hydrazinehydrate 2 (2 mmol), aromatic aldehyde 3 (1 mmol) and malononitrile 4 (1 mmol), in the presence of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocatalyst (5 mg) was reacted in ethanol at 40 °C. The completion of the reaction was monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC). After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was easily separated by an external magnet. The pure products were obtained from the reaction mixture by recrystallization from hot EtOH and no more purification was required. All the product were known compounds which were identified by characterization of their melting points (as indicated in Table 2) by comparison with those authentic literature samples and also in some cases their FT-IR. 2.6 Spectral data of the selected products 6-Amino-3-methyl-4-(3-nitrophenyl)-1,4-dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole-5-carbonitrile (5b): IR (KBr: υ/cm−1): 3473, 3220, 2194, 1654, 1604, 1521, 1350; 1H-NMR (500 MHz, 6): δ H (ppm) = 1.80 (3H, s, CH3), 4.78 (1H, s, CH), 7.04 (2H, s, NH2), 7.65 (2H, m, H-Ar), 8.02 (1H, s, H-Ar), 8.12 (1H, dd, J = 7.7 Hz, H-Ar), 12.20 (1H, s, NH); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6); δ C (ppm) = 9.7, 35.6, 56.1, 96.6, 120.5, 121.8, 121.9, 130.2, 134.3, 135.9, 146.8, 147.9, 154.7, 171.1. 6-Amino-4-(4-chlorophenyl)-3-methyl-2,4-dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole-5-carbonitrile (5d): IR (KBr: υ/cm−1): 3483, 3236, 2187, 1641, 1598 cm-1; 1H-NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ H (ppm) = 1.79 (3H, s, CH3), 4.63 (1H, s, CH), 6.91 (2H, s, NH2), 7.19–7.20 (2H, d, J = 8 Hz, H-Ar), 7.37–7.38 (2H, d, J = 8 Hz, H-Ar), 12.12 (1H, s, NH); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6); δ C (ppm) = 10.2, 36.0, 57.3, 97.6, 121.0, 128.9, 129.8, 131.7, 136.1, 143.9, 155.2, 161.4. 6-Amino-4-(4-hydroxyphenyl)-3-methyl-2,4-dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole-5-carbonitrile (5e): IR (KBr: υ/cm−1): 3355, 3170, 2187, 1649, 1604 cm-1; 1H-NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ H (ppm) = 1.78 (3H, s, CH3), 4.47 (1H, s, CH), 6.68–6.69 (2H, d, J = 8 Hz, H-Ar), 6.76 (2H, s, NH2), 6.94–6.96 (2H, d, J = 8 Hz, H-Ar), 9.25 (1H, s, OH) 12.03 (1H, s, NH); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6); δ C (ppm) = 10.2, 35.9, 58.3, 98.5, 115.6, 121.3, 128.9, 135.2, 135.9, 155.2, 156.5, 161.1. 6-Amino-3-methyl-4-(p-tolyl)-2,4-dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole-5-carbonitrile (5f): IR (KBr: υ/cm−1): 3413, 3299, 2194, 1641, 1614 cm-1; 1H-NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ H (ppm) = 1.77 (3H, s, CH3), 2.25 (3H, s, CH3), 4.53 (1H, s, CH), 6.82 (2H, s, NH2), 7.07 (4H, m, H-Ar), 12.07 (1H, s, NH); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6); δ C (ppm) = 10.2, 21.0, 36.3, 57.9, 98.2, 121.2, 127.8, 129.4, 136.0, 136.1, 141.9, 155.2, 161.2. 6-Amino-4-(4-cyanophenyl)-3-methyl-2,4-dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole-5-carbonitrile (5 h): IR (KBr: υ/cm−1): 3483, 3226, 2227, 2187, 1641, 1598 cm-1; 1H-NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ H (ppm) = 1.83 (3H, s, CH3), 4.75 (1H, s, CH), 7.00 (2H, s, NH2), 7.37–7.39 (2H, d, J = 8.5 Hz, H-Ar), 7.79–7.81 (2H, d, J = 8.5 Hz, H-Ar), 12.17 (1H, s, NH); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6); δ C (ppm) = 10.6, 36.6, 56.5, 97.1, 110.1, 119.2, 120.4, 129.0, 133.0, 136.2, 150.5, 155.2, 160.6. 6-Amino-4-(furan-2-yl)-3-methyl-1,4-dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole-5-carbonitrile (5 l): IR (KBr: υ/cm−1): 3355, 3170, 2187, 1649, 1604 cm-1; 1H-NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ H (ppm) = 1.96 (3H, s, CH3), 4.77 (1H, s, CH), 6.17 (1H, H-Ar), 6.36 (1H, H-Ar), 6.93 (1H, s, NH2), 7.52 (1H, H-Ar), 12.14 (1H, s, NH); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6); δ C (ppm) = 9.5, 29.8, 54.0, 95.1, 105.6, 110.2, 120.5, 135.8, 142.2, 154.8, 155.7, 161.4. 3 Results and discussion In this work, a novel, environmentally friendly, simple and low cost nanocatalyst was fabricated by loading PEI on magnetic halloysite nanotubes. Initially, Fe3O4@HNTs nanocomposite was synthesis. After that, this synthesized nanocomposite modified by PEI to prepare Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocatalyst (Scheme 1). The FT-IR, FE-SEM, EDX, XRD, TGA, VSM analyzes were performed for studding the structure and chemical properties of nanocomposite. All of these analyzes indicated the formation of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI with unique features such as nanotube morphology, thermal stability, crystalline nature and acceptable magnetic property. The synthesized nanocomposite was used as a reusable catalyst for synthesis of dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives without any significant loss of catalyst activity. 3.1 Characterization of the prepared Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocatalyst FT-IR spectroscopy was performed to detect the chemical properties and structural of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI (Fig. 1 ). The comparison of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI, Fe3O4@HNTs and HNTs spectra can confirm the synthesis of nanocatalyst. As can be seen in the FT-IR spectrum of HNTs, the stretching vibrations of inner-surface Al−OH were depicted in 3695.36 and 3627.85 cm−1. The bands at 536 and 468 cm−1 were assigned to the bending vibration of AlOSi and SiOSi, respectively. The peak at 911.42 cm−1 was attributed to the bending vibration of Al−OH of HNTs [31]. The above-mentioned peaks all appeared in Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI, Fe3O4@HNTs spectra. The broad band at 3424.98 cm−1 in Fe3O4@HNTs spectrum was due to stretching vibrations of hydroxyl groups from iron oxide and the Fe3O4 characteristic peak at around 550 cm−1 was overlapped with the bending vibration of AlOSi [32]. In the spectrum of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI, two peaks at 1464 and 1631 cm−1 are related to the symmetric and asymmetric bending vibration of NH2. Furthermore, it was found that the stretching vibration of alkyl groups in the PEI was depicted at 2856 and 2914 cm−1 [33]. In order to illustrate the relationship between the FT-IR and the content of PEI, the elemental compositions of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocomposite was determined through EDX. The result of the EDX analysis of the Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocomposite is found in Fig. 2 b. It confirms the presence of iron, carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, aluminum and siliconelements in the nanocatalyst. Also, the EDX analysis was used to ensure that the 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane was loaded on the surface of magnetic halloysite as a linker (Fig. 2a). The surface morphology and size details of the nanocatalyst were investigated by FE-SEM measurements in two different magnifications, which are illustrated in Fig. 3 . FE-SEM (Fig. 3a) revealed some roughness on the surface of HNTs nanotubes due to grafted PEI. However, it indicated that the surface morphology of HNTs does not alter extremely in the presence of Fe3O4 and PEI. As can be seen in Fig. 3b, the Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocatalyst has a uniform size distribution with an average size of 55 ± 16 nm. The thermal behaviour of the prepared nanocatalyst was evaluated by TGA analysis over the temperature range of 50–800 °C in the air atmosphere and heating rates at 10 °C/min. As can be seen in TGA curves in Fig. 4 , a weight loss between 50–250 °C is related to evaporation of solvents and other molecules which are physically absorbed on to the surface of HNTs (Fig. 4a), Fe3O4@HNTs (Fig. 4b) and Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI (Fig. 4c). Moreover, HNTs and Fe3O4@HNTs exhibited higher thermal stability than 600 °C. In the curve of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocomposite, the new weight loss about 20% occurred in the temperature range between 300–550 °C corresponding to the decomposition of PEI groups on Fe3O4-halloysite [17]. The weight loss of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI was continued at around 550 °C, while according to the literature, PEI was decomposed at the temperature below 400 °C [34]. So, the chemical absorption of PEI on the surface of magnetic halloysite can be concluded. As a result, thermal decomposition of nanocomposite which was started at 250 °C exhibit remarkable thermal stability of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI. To investigate the crystal structure and composition of the nanocomposite, the XRD measurement was used (Fig. 5 ). Comparison of the XRD patterns of Fe3O4@HNTs and Fe3O4@HNTs- PEI shows that the structure of iron oxide and halloysite in both of them are similar and the positions of characteristic peaks did not shift. It can be concluded that PEI has reacted only on the outer surface of the halloysite. All of the observed peaks of magnetite iron oxide with the cubic crystalstructure at the diffraction angles (2θ) of 30.80, 36.05, 43.60, 54.29, 57.98 and 63.41 are similar to the characteristic data of (JCPDS card no. 01-075-0449). Also, the diffraction angles (2θ) 12.27, 20.20, 24.99, 36.05 and 63.41 of halloysite attributed to the hexagonal structure (JCPDS card no. 00-029-1487). A noteworthy synthesis of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI was confirmed by the magnetic property of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocomposite. In the previously reported study, the magnetization of neat Fe3O4 nanoparticles was 56 electromagnetic units per gram (emu g−1) [35]. As illustrated by VSM analysis in Fig. 6 , the saturation magnetization values of Fe3O4@HNTs (a) and Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI (b) nanocomposite were around 30 and 15 emu g−1. The decrease of the saturation magnetization of Fe3O4 MNPs after loading to the halloysite and coating PEI on the surface of nanocomposite confirmed the successfully grafting of PEI groups on the magnetic halloysite nanotube. Nevertheless, this magnetic property cause to easy separation of catalyst from the reaction mixture by an external magnet. 3.2 Catalytic application of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocatalyst in the synthesis of dihydropyrano [2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives The four-component reaction of benzaldehyde 1, malononitrile 2, ethyl acetoacetate 3 and hydrazinehydrate was chosen as the model reaction to optimize the reaction. The effects of the different solvents, catalyst and various amounts of catalyst on the reaction efficiency were evaluated and indicated in Table 1 . The model reaction was studied in H2O and EtOH as green solvents. The reaction yield in H2O and the presence of different amount of catalyst was not significantly improved (Table 1, entries 1–3), also the yield of the desired product 5a in H2O was significantly less than EtOH under similar catalyst loading. In the presence of iron nanoparticles, halloysite and magnetic halloysite, the reaction efficiency was low (Table 1, entries 4–6) but after using Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocatalyst in the same reaction conditions the reaction yield increased remarkably to 96% (Table 1, entry 10) and it confirmed the synergistic effect of Fe3O4, HNTs and PEI. Moreover, the effect of the different amount of catalyst was examined (entries 7–11). As can be seen (Table 1, entry 10) In the presence of 50 mg of the catalyst, a significant yield was obtained. While, the yield of the desired product 5b was not increased in the excess amount of catalyst (Table 1, entry 11). The results clearly demonstrate the superiority of the present work in saving time, energy and high yields of the products can be obtained by carrying out the reaction at ambient condition in ethanol and using 50 mg of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI catalyst. After optimizing the reaction conditions, we investigated the generality of these conditions using various aromatic aldehydes. Moreover, all the aromatic aldehydes having either electron-withdrawing or electrondonating substitutes reacted easily to provide the corresponding dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives (5a-l) in mild reaction conditions. The results are summarized in Table 2 . It was found that all products were obtained in high-to-excellent yields after appropriate reaction times. A plausible mechanism for the formation of pyranopyrazole derivatives is depicted in Scheme 2 . As can be seen, Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI NPs plays an important role in all part of the reaction mechanism. On the basis of the literature [38] and substrates chemistry, the first step is the formation of pyrazolone ring (I) via cyclocondensation by activation of ethyl acetoacetate with Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI and nucleophilic attack of hydrazine upon the carbonyl group of it. After losing H2O, another group of hydrazine attacked to the next carbonyl group of ethyl acetoacetate and provided pyrazolone ring by removal of EtOH. In the second step, Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI activated carbonyl group of aldehydes and produced 4´ to form 2-phenylidenemalononitrile (II) by Knoevenagel reaction. Michael addition between intermediate I and II gave compound III. Finally, the enolization and cyclization of intermediate III provided IIII and finally, it was followed by tautomerization of compound IIII to afford 5a-l. 3.3 Reusability study of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocatalyst Catalyst’s reusability is among the most significant factors in view of industrial and commercial aspects. Therefore, the reusability of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocatalyst was evaluated in the model reaction. In this regard, after completion of the reaction, the nanocatalyst was recovered by an external magnet, washed several times with ethanol, and dried. It was found that this finalized nanocatalyst can be reused in subsequent reactions at least 8 times without any significant decrease in yield of the products (Fig. 7 ). Finally, as can be seen in Figs. S5 and S6, the recycled catalyst was characterized by the FT-IR and EDX analyses. These result confirmed that the Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocatalyst was stable, magnetically retrievable and reusable. 4 Conclusions In summary, a novel and environmentally-benign poly(ethylene imine)-functionalized magnetic halloysite nanotubes (Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI) have been synthesized and completely characterized by FT-IR, FE-SEM, EDX, TGA, XRD and VSM analyses, which indicated the successful chemical functionalization of PEI with magnetic halloysite. This nanocomposite shows unique feathers such as nanotube morphology, thermal stability, crystal structure and magnetic property. Then, the catalytic activity of the nanocomposite was evaluated in the synthesis of dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives. The products were obtained in high-to-excellent yields at room temperature under mild reaction conditions. The nanocatalyst was easily separated by an external magnetic field and reused efficiently for the several times without significant loss in catalytic activities. This is the first report on design, preparation, functionalization and characterization of the present nanocomposite and performance as a heterogeneous catalyst in organic reactions. coredata.dc:description: In this study, a green magnetic nanocatalyst based on natural clay was fabricated. Magnetic nanoparticles were loaded on halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) and poly(ethylene imine) (PEI) was covalently grafted onto the surface of HNTs. The morphology and chemistry of the Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI nanocomposite was fully characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy spectra, field-emission scanning electron micrograph (FE-SEM) images, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern and vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) curve analyses. These characteristics confirmed the successful synthesis of the nanocomposite. The catalytic performance of Fe3O4@HNTs-PEI was utilized for the synthesis of pyranopyrazole derivatives. This heterogeneous catalyst exhibited high efficiency in green media under mild reaction conditions at room temperature and can be easily recovered from the reaction mixture by using an external magnet and reused for at least eight times without any significant decrease in catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Poly(ethylene imine)-modified magnetic halloysite nanotubes: A novel, efficient and recyclable catalyst for the synthesis of dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives
